text:
Unsure what channel (or community!) to ask this is, I figure some of the wise folks in here will have insight.

My client won a recent award from a UK publication and included their logo on a press release — and got a cease and desist for unauthorized use of the logo!

They’re curious if they need to secure rights/permissions for all news outlet orgs/logos. Gut level, I suspect they don’t need to and this award + C&D is just a scam.

Anyone have a link to an article, guide, etc., that talks about securing rights/permission for news outlet orgs in order to use their logo on the site/in press releases?

They have press pieces/awards from NYT, People, WIRED, etc., and _aren’t using any of them (!!!)_ because they’re uncertain on if they need to pay for logo rights.

What say you, Superpath minds? :brain:

elements.text:

They’re curious if they need to secure rights/permissions for all news outlet orgs/logos. Gut level, I suspect they don’t need to and this award + C&D is just a scam.

Anyone have a link to an article, guide, etc., that talks about securing rights/permission for news outlet orgs in order to use their logo on the site/in press releases?

They have press pieces/awards from NYT, People, WIRED, etc., and

because they’re uncertain on if they need to pay for logo rights.

What say you, Superpath minds?

text: I would probably encourage them to look at any language they received when they got these awards. There might be some language around what they can and can't do when publishing information about awards. Companies have to protect their brand after all. You will never know unless you read contracts or reach out to the initial contact who shared the award win with  them.
